Award.AwardTitle: Functional Analysis of Cilia in Hedgehog Signaling and Gli Activity Regulation
Award.AbstractNarration: Hedgehog (Hh) family of secreted proteins is critical for cell proliferation and cell fate determination in animal development. The PI recently showed cilia, tiny 'hairs' on top of most mammalian cells, are needed for cells to respond to Hh. In this proposal, the PI will investigate whether and how cilia influence the ability of Gli proteins, a group of three proteins involved in gene expression regulation, to mediate the cell's response to Hh. First, the PI will genetically test the hypothesis that cilia are essential for the activation of all three Gli proteins. Subsequently, the PI will investigate the mechanisms by which these Gli proteins are transported into the cilia, using cell biological and biochemical approaches. Finally, the PI will test the hypothesis that Gli proteins cannot be activated without getting into cilia by genetically engineering Gli proteins such that they are no longer transported into the cilia. The research program proposed here will not only elucidate the mechanism by which cilia regulate the activities of Gli proteins, but also provide more general insight into how basic cellular machinery regulates information flow to ensure normal development of an animal. The integration of research and education will be achieved by applying the research material to undergraduate teaching, encouraging undergraduate students to participate in lab research and providing opportunities for graduate students to be involved in teaching activities. Female and minority students will be recruited to participate in this project through NASA sponsored programs. Finally, the PI will be actively involved in outreach activities such as hosting high school students and participating in lecture series aimed at disseminating scientific knowledge to the local community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

 

Most cells in a mammal grow primary cilia, tiny hair-like protrusions on their surface that are crucial for development and physiology. Specifically, Hedgehog (Hh) proteins coordinate the behavior of many cells in a mammal to ensure its survival and proper function. We found that cells need the cilia to respond to Hh proteins, and our aim was to understand how the cilia regulate this important cellular function.

Most mammalian cells respond to Hh proteins by activating Gli family of proteins that subsequently turn on gene expression. We previously showed that cilia are important for the activation of Gli2, the primary Gli activator in early development. Gli1 is another important Gli family member but it was not clear how cilia regulate its activation. We replaced Gli2 with Gli1 through a genetic approach, and made a surprising discovery: when Gli1 acts as the primary activator in early development, cells without cilia appear to be more sensitive to Hh proteins than those with normal cilia. We hypothesized that the total level of Gli proteins in the cell influences how cells respond to Hh proteins in the presence/absence of cilia, and one of our future research directions will be to further test this hypothesis.

Gli family proteins and their binding partner, Suppressor of Fused (Sufu), were found at the tips of the primary cilia. We investigated how this localization was regulated and found that the central part of each Gli protein (namely the ciliary localization domain, or CLD) was needed for the Gli proteins to travel to the cilia. We also found that increasing the level of cAMP, an important small messenger molecule, efficiently blocked the trafficking of Gli and Sufu proteins to the cilia. cAMP is important for the activation of cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA), which adds phosphate groups to the Gli proteins. However, mutating four known PKA target sites on Gli proteins does not block Gli ciliary trafficking, suggesting either an indirect function of PKA or other cAMP-dependent mechanisms prevent Gli accumulation in the cilia. Finally, we found that although Sufu does not appear to regulate Gli ciliary localization, Gli proteins are essential for the ciliary localization of Sufu. These results provided strong support to our model in which Sufu and Gli proteins enter the cilia in the form of a pre-assembled complex. This work was published in PloS ONE in 2010.

Finally, we investigated whether trafficking to the cilia is a requirement for the activation of Gli2, the primary activator of the Hh signaling pathway in early development. We approach this question by replacing the normal Gli2 gene with one lacking the CLD domain in the mouse using state-of-the art genetic engineering tools. Our preliminary data suggest that cells making this “non-ciliary Gli2” fail to respond to Hh proteins in development. We are now performing additional experiments with this mutant mouse line to show ciliary trafficking is indeed very important for Gli protein activation.

Initially as a control experiment, we investigated the genetic interaction between Gli proteins and Sufu. Soon we realized that this topic itself was very important for our understanding of how cells respond to Hh proteins in development. We expanded our study and found that the three Gli proteins play distinct roles in Hh pathway activation in the absence of Sufu, and rather surprisingly, we identified an unappreciated positive role of Sufu, which was widely conceived as a negative regulator of Gli proteins (Liu et al, 2012).
